full_title_en: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Rumination Syndrome
medium_description_en: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of rumination syndrome.
instructions_en:
Use in patients with symptoms suggestive of rumination syndrome, such as persistent or recurrent regurgitation of recently ingested food into the mouth with subsequent spitting or remastication and swallowing, for at least the past 6 months.

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though rumination syndrome may be present:

  • Signs or symptoms of GI bleeding.

  • Unexplained iron deficiency anemia.

  • Heartburn.

  • Esophageal reflux/regurgitation.

  • Unintentional weight loss.

  • Palpable abdominal mass or lymphadenopathy on exam.

  • Family history of gastric cancer and no recent upper endoscopy.

  • Dysphagia.

  • Persistent vomiting.

how_to_use.use_case_en: Patients presenting with recurrent regurgitation of recently ingested food into the mouth for at least the past 6 months. The diagnosis of rumination syndrome should be made by clinical history, physical examination, and minimal laboratory tests. Diagnostic testing may include combined esophageal impedance/high resolution manometry.
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• A diagnosis of rumination can only be made after a careful diagnostic workup reveals no evidence of organic, systemic, or metabolic disease to explain the symptoms, which may include combined esophageal impedance/high resolution manometry.

  • Regurgitation is not preceded by wretching; it is effortless.

  • Regurgitation is not associated with nausea.

  • Regurgitant contains recognizable food that might have a pleasant taste.

  • The rumination process tends to cease when the regurgitated material becomes acidic.

  • Many patients with rumination syndrome show evidence of pathologic GERD on diagnostic testing.

  • Rumination syndrome can be associated with bulimia nervosa.
how_to_use.why_use_en:
• Helps to make a diagnosis of rumination syndrome when appropriate workup of upper GI symptoms is nondiagnostic.

  • Helps to distinguish symptoms from other common disorders, such as GERD.

next_steps.advice_en:
If diagnostic criteria are not met (negative):

Symptoms are unlikely to be caused by rumination syndrome. Consider further assessment for other diseases, or a different functional GI disorder.

If meets diagnosis (positive):

Likely diagnosis of rumination syndrome.
next_steps.management_en:
Management of rumination syndrome may include:

  • Diaphragmatic breathing.

  • Proton pump inhibitors.

  • Neuromodulators (e.g. low dose tricyclic antidepressants).

  • Baclofen.
next_steps.critical_actions_en:
• This calculator should only be used in patients after appropriate organic, systemic, and metabolic causes have been ruled out after careful investigation.

  • Note: patients with rumination syndrome may have evidence of pathologic GERD on diagnostic testing.

about.formula_en:
To fulfill the Rome IV criteria for rumination syndrome*, patient must have the following (for 3 months prior with symptom onset ≥6 months ago):

  1. Persistent or recurrent regurgitation of recently ingested food into the mouth with subsequent spitting or remastication and swallowing.
  2. Regurgitation is not preceded by retching.

*Note:

  1. Effortless regurgitation events are usually not preceded by nausea.
  2. Regurgitant contains recognizable food that might have a pleasant taste.
  3. The process tends to cease when the regurgitated material becomes acidic.
about.evidence_based_medicine_en:
The Rome criteria were initially developed as a way to classify and diagnose the various disorders of gut brain interaction (DGBI) such as functional dyspepsia, functional constipation, and irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) based primarily on symptoms.

The development of the Rome IV questionnaires began with a survey of 1,162 adults without gastrointestinal disorders to determine the frequency in the US general population of various gastrointestinal symptoms. The 90th percentile of symptom frequency was used to define what was considered an abnormal frequency of symptoms. Based on this, diagnostic questionnaires were created and reviewed by clinical experts.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Stanghellini V, Chan FK, Hasler WL, et al. Gastroduodenal Disorders. Gastroenterology. 2016;150(6):1380-92.

creator_info.about_en: Douglas Drossman, MD, is professor emeritus of medicine and psychiatry at the University of North Carolina School of Medicine. He is founder, President Emeritus and Chief of Operations of the Rome Foundation. He is also the founder of the Drossman Center for the Education and Practice of Biopsychosocial Care and Drossman Consulting, LLC. Dr. Drossman has written over 500 articles and book chapters, has published two books, a GI procedure manual and a textbook of functional GI disorders (Rome I-IV), and serves on six editorial and advisory boards.

Lin Chang, MD is responsible for the oversight and coordination of the Rome IV calculators on MDCalc. She is a Professor of Medicine at the Vatche and Tamar Manoukian Division of Digestive Diseases at UCLA and is a member of the Rome Foundation Board of Directors.

The Rome Foundation is an independent not for profit 501(c) 3 organization that provides support for activities designed to create scientific data and educational information to assist in the diagnosis and treatment of Disorders of Gut-Brain Interaction (DGBI), also known as functional gastrointestinal (GI) disorders. Their mission is to improve the lives of people with DGBI. Over the last 3 decades, the Rome organization has sought to legitimize and update our knowledge of the DGBIs. This has been accomplished by bringing together scientists and clinicians from around the world to classify and critically appraise the science of GI function and dysfunction. This knowledge permits clinical scientists to make recommendations for diagnosis and treatment that can be applied in research and clinical practice. Diagnosis is based on the use of symptom-based criteria which are used in clinical trials and daily practice.
